Dialog.Topics: Robert Chote on the irrelevance of the credit rating agencies

Turn.Utterance: Osbourne used the triple A credit rating and the retention of it as a justification to push through his oxymoronic "expansionary fiscal contraction". Telling any who would listen that the markets would crucify us if we lost it.Now it looks as though we might,well it's not such a big deal after all now,he says.What a imbecilic,useless chancellor he is.

If it is lost and the market response, measured by the change in UK borrowing costs, was "meh" (which it obviously would be) , then one of the primary justifications for current government policy would look a tad silly. As would the chancellor - so either it does matter and he's the man who lost our coveted AAA status or it doesnt and its a u-turn after inflicting avoidable pain.
It feels so nice to find somebody with some original thoughts on this subjectEvent Staffing AgencyReally thankful to you for starting this.

And if further evidence of the ratings agencies being a lagging indicator were required:http://fivethirtyeight.blogs.nytimes.com/2011/08/08/why-s-p-s-ratings-are-substandard-and-porous/The 10yr UK Gilt yields about 1.73%... markets have already priced in a protracted period of low growth with no apparent fears of outright default (or implicit default through inflation)
